It is generally believed that individuals with sociopathic tendencies can understand the concepts of right and wrong on an intellectual level. They may know what is expected of them in terms of societal norms and moral values but lack the emotional and empathetic capacity to truly internalize these values and apply them in real-life situations. This is because sociopaths have a reduced capacity for emotions such as empathy, guilt, and remorse, which are crucial for understanding and adhering to moral values.

However, it is important to note that not all individuals with sociopathic tendencies are the same, and the severity of their condition can vary. Some sociopaths may have more capacity for empathy and moral reasoning than others, even if they do not fully grasp the concepts of right and wrong in the same way as people without sociopathy. Additionally, therapy and other interventions can help some individuals with sociopathic tendencies develop moral reasoning skills and increase their capacity for empathy, although a complete transformation may be difficult to achieve.
